['Here are some common responses:', 'Sadness – A profound feeling of sorrow or unhappiness due to loss.', 'Loneliness – The sense of isolation that can come from losing a close connection with another person.', 'Despair – Feeling without hope, often as if the future is bleak and joyless because something significant has been taken away.', 'Denial – Initially refusing to accept or believe in the loss; this may be part of the grieving process itself.', 'Anger – This can be directed towards oneself, others, circumstances, or even God/the divine for allowing such a loss.', 'Guilt – Feeling responsible for the death or as if one could have prevented it in some way; this is common especially when there might feel like there are things left unsaid or undone.', 'Depression – A state of persistent low mood and feeling of sadness, which can become a more severe mental health condition requiring professional intervention.', 'Yearning – An intense longing for the deceased person; this desire may feel overwhelming at times.', 'Shock/Numbness – The inability to comprehend or react appropriaturally to the death, often as a temporary measure by which individuals protect themselves from overwhelming emotions.', "Preoccupation with the deceased – Difficulty moving on mentally and emotionally; constantly thinking about what they're missing in life without that person.", 'Changes in sleeping or eating patterns – Grief can disrupt normal routines, leading to insomnia, nightmares, or changes in appetite.', 'Physical symptoms – Stress and grief can manifest as physical pain, fatigue, nausea, shortness of breath, heart palpitations, etc.', 'Anxiety/Fearful thoughts – Concerns about the future or fear of losing someone else close to them.', 'Searching for meaning – Trying to make sense of why this happened and what it means in a broader context, which can lead to spiritual questioning.', 'Changes in self-perception – Feeling less capable or confident following the loss; sometimes grief forces individuals to redefine their sense of identity without that person in their life.', 'Complicated Grief (Prolonged) – When symptoms persist for an extended period and interfere with daily functioning, suggesting a more serious condition known as complicated or persistent complex bereavement disorder may be developing.', 'It is important to remember that everyone experiences grief differently; there isn’t a "right" way to feel after a loss, nor does it follow the same timeline for every person.']
